messages: ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:29): Star rating widgets are often interactive, so you can click on the nth star to submit a rating of n
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:29): so <progress> won't work there - what's a good alternative?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (01:31): <meter> without initial value?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (01:31): wonders if that's possible
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:32): Er, I meant <meter> not <progress>

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:32): Rating: <a href=vote?1><img src=onstar alt='Current rating: 2 out of 3. Submit your vote: 1' title='Vote 1/3'></a><a href=vote?2><img src=onstar alt=2 title='Vote 2/3'></a><a href=vote?3><img src=offstar alt=3 title='Vote 3/3'></a>
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:32): logically speaking it's a input type="range"
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:32): perhaps
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (01:33): yeah and once submitted it's converted into <meter>
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (01:33): could work
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (01:33): once the CSS/XBL story actually works for form controls
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:33): yep
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:33): if it ever does
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:34): still doesn't like depending on technologies that don't exist yet
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:35): best current way would probably be to put a click event handler on every star
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:36): (since you probably want to submit the rating in some ajaxy way)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:36): or you could make them <input type="image"> and have an onsubmit handler on the form do the async submission

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:37): If it's done with multiple images, I'm wondering what suitable alt text should be, since it needs to convey the value of each star and the current rating, and there are ~5 separate alt attributes to spread the text across
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:39): it's certainly fiddly
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:40): logically, it's an <input type="range" min="1" max="5">
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:40): but XBL binding that to look right - good luck
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:41): I guess input type="number" might be more appropriate
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:41): (same min and max)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:41): you could use alt to represent the state and "title" on each star to indicate what clicking it will do
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:41): It should be possible to write conforming HTML5 that works in legacy browsers
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:41): in which case you can't use new <input> types or XBL
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:41): assuming you use input type="image

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:43): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: The issue (or at least the one I'm pretending to care about) is that you then have multiple images conveying a single piece of information (the current rating), and alt is defined to only be about the information conveyed by a single image
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:43): could also be a fieldset of radio buttons
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:43): <form onsubmit="changeRating(event)"><input type="image" alt="" title="set rating to 1/5"><input type="image" alt="2/5"....>
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:43): where 2/5 is the current rating
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:43): that might not give good results in a screen reader though
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:44): You should be able to vote for the current rating too (where 'current rating' is determined by other voters)

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:45): <fieldset><legend>Rating: 2 out of 5</legend><input type="image" alt="Set rating to 1 out of 5"><img alt=""><input type="image" alt="Set rating to 3 out of 5">...</fieldset>
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:45): maybe
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (01:46): Problem with developing print style sheets in Prince: you forget how bad actual browsers are at all the page CSS (i.e., css3-page, css3-gcpm).
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:49): would using ARIA to pretend the star control is a spinbox work?

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (01:50): this is really a case where you can easily build the UI you want for non-disabled users, but you want a low-level accessibility API to make things great for the visually or motor impaired
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:51): i'm sure you could do /something/ with ARIA.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:52): that sounds reasonable.

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:53): "This functionality should be accomplished programmatically through the use of up and down arrows on the keyboard." (http://www.w3.org/TR/wai-aria/#spinbutton) ... would be better if they didn't specify particular keys though!

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:54): Seems like there's a danger that for any accessibility-related problem, I could just say that ARIA can probably solve it, so that's okay, and then I don't actually know how to use ARIA and haven't got a clue how to test it even if I did use it, so I'll just leave it until later (i.e. never implement it)
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:54): yep

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:54): I can cope with understanding accessibility at the level of "if all images are replaced by their alt text, the page should still be usable", but that's about it
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:56): easiest way to test these things is to ask some real users to test them (e.g. jaws-users mailing list, <email/> etc.)
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:57): VO/FireVox/Orca/NVDA are also relatively easy to learn, though hard to use the same as someone who needs to use them in anger.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:57): Hmm, I think I consider other people's time too valuable to ask them to review my rubbish web apps :-)
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:57): Opera Voice is another interesting one
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:58): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: It's a mailing list, they can always ignore you :) ... they're often keen to help webdevs in passing though.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:58): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Also, if you can generalize the technique at all, then you can publish it and save someone else the testing.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:59): If they ignored me and didn't waste their time, that'd be wasting my time instead, so it'd be better to just not ask :-)
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (01:59): Only with the advantage of hindsight.
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:00): Seems like it would be a useful resource if I was doing anything that actually had users, though
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:00): with this theoretical spinboxy thing, I wonder whether Opera Voice would use the ARIA role or the non-ARIA markup or what
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:01): Does Opera Voice understand ARIA?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:01): (Is there a test somewhere to find out?)
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:01): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: Do you know whether Opera Voice is using the ARIA stuff being implemented in Kestrel?

ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:02): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: Problem is knowing what one's testing. First you'd need to find a nice ARIA test, then check Opera is exposing it to MSAA, the check what OV does.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:02): and even though it's a bit hard to know
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:02): OV's a bit buggy.
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:02): (e.g. in 9.x, you can't open links in the content area)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (02:02): wishes Opera Voice worked on Linux
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:02): we really want it to be possible for the platform to let you build an accessible rating control
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:02): whatever the mechanism
ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee (02:03): another option might be to using aria tristate checkboxes

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (02:12): might be a good idea to consider what the ideal ui for this rating control would be, for the non-visual user
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:13): ef6f2287bae00ba79475fbf56c2b6fee: I don't think tristate is the right model for that
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (02:13): the mixed state of tristate checkboxes is supposed to be for when they represent state of a group of things that is currently mixed
